docs.title: Travel Documents & Visas
docs.description: Most foreign nationals require a visa to enter India. The e-Visa system is available for many nationalities, simplifying the process.
points: Apply for an e-Visa online at least 4 days before your arrival.
Passport must have at least six months validity from the date of arrival.
Your passport must have at least two blank pages for the visa.
Keep digital and physical copies of your passport and visa.

culture.title: Culture & Traditions
culture.description: India is a mosaic of diverse cultures, languages, and religions. Hospitality is a cornerstone, and guests are often treated with great respect.
points: Use your right hand for eating and handling money.
Dress modestly, especially when visiting religious sites (cover shoulders and knees).
'Namaste' is a common greeting, said with palms pressed together.
Remove shoes before entering a home or temple.

safety.title: Safety & Precautions
safety.description: While generally safe for tourists, it's important to be cautious, especially in crowded areas. Be aware of common scams.
points: Be wary of overly friendly strangers offering unsolicited help or tours.
Agree on taxi and auto-rickshaw fares before starting your journey.
Avoid walking alone at night in isolated areas.
Drink only bottled or purified water.

health.title: Health & Diseases
health.description: Consult a doctor for recommended vaccinations like Typhoid and Hepatitis A. Food and water-borne illnesses are common, so be cautious with what you eat and drink.
points: Avoid street food unless it's freshly cooked in front of you.
Carry a basic medical kit with essentials like diarrhea medication and antiseptic.
Use mosquito repellent to protect against Dengue and Malaria.
Private hospitals in major cities offer good quality care.

money.title: Money & Budget
money.description: The currency is the Indian Rupee (INR). ATMs are widely available in cities, but it's good to carry some cash, especially in rural areas.
points: Inform your bank about your travel plans to avoid card blockage.
Bargaining is common in markets, but not in shops with fixed prices.
A budget of ₹2,500-₹4,000 per day is reasonable for mid-range travel.
Credit cards are accepted in hotels and larger establishments.

connectivity.title: Connectivity & Transport
connectivity.description: India's transport network is vast and varied, from extensive railways to budget airlines. Ride-sharing apps like Uber and Ola are popular in cities.
points: Booking trains in advance is recommended, especially on popular routes.
Domestic flights are an efficient way to cover long distances.
Get a local SIM card for affordable data and calls.
Be prepared for traffic and delays in major cities.

adaptation.title: Adaptation & Mindset
adaptation.description: India can be an intense and overwhelming experience. A flexible attitude and a sense of humor are your best travel companions.
points: Embrace the 'organized chaos'; things may not always go as planned.
Be patient and polite, even in frustrating situations.
The concept of personal space is different; be prepared for crowds.
Be open to new experiences and engage with the friendly local people.
